sub_topic: The Hausdorff dimension of the Koch curve.
message_1: What is the Hausdorff dimension of the Koch curve, where each iteration adds four times the original length and removes the middle third of each line segment, starting with an initial line segment of length 1?
message_2:
To find the Hausdorff dimension of the Koch curve, we can use the formula:

Hausdorff dimension = log(N) / log(M)

where N is the number of self-similar pieces and M is the scaling factor.

For the Koch curve, at each iteration, the curve is divided into 4 self-similar pieces (N = 4), and each piece is 1/3 the length of the previous iteration (M = 3).

So, the Hausdorff dimension of the Koch curve is:

Hausdorff dimension = log(4) / log(3) â‰ˆ 1.2619
